terms.definition: Inability to perform any physical activity without discomfort - anginal symptoms may be present at rest.
synonyms: Canadian Cardiovascular Society Grading Scale Class IV

codelists.definition: A terminology codelist associated with coronary artery disease presentation.
codelists.name: Coronary Artery Disease Presentation
synonyms: CDISC SDTM Coronary Artery Disease Presentation Terminology

terms.definition: A myocardial infarction that does not produce elevation in the ST segments of the ECG.
A myocardial infarction that produces elevation in the ST segments of the ECG.
synonyms: ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction by ECG Finding

terms.definition: Angina pectoris which has not recently changed in frequency, duration or intensity. Stable angina pectoris is relieved by rest or administration of oral, sublingual or transdermal antianginal medications.
Angina pectoris (or equivalent type of ischemic discomfort) which has recently changed in frequency, duration, intensity, or occurs at rest.
A variant form of angina pectoris caused by coronary artery vasospasm, usually occurring spontaneously and frequently associated with ST segment elevation.

codelists.definition: A terminology codelist to describe the relative risk of coronary artery disease.
codelists.name: Coronary Artery Disease Risk
synonyms: CDISC SDTM Coronary Artery Disease Risk Terminology

terms.definition: The likelihood an individual will develop coronary artery disease is almost certain or greater than 90%. (Gibbons RJ, Balady GJ, Bricker JT, Chaitman BR, Fletcher GF, Froelicher VF, Mark DB, McCallister BD, Mooss AN, O'Reilly MG, Winters WL Jr. ACC/AHA 2002 guideline update for exercise testing: a report of the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association Task Force on Practice Guidelines (Committee on Exercise Testing). 2002. American College of Cardiology Web site. Available at: www.acc.org/clinical/guidelines/exercise/dirIndex.htm.)

The likelihood an individual will develop coronary artery disease (CAD) is moderate or between 10% and 90%. (Gibbons RJ, Balady GJ, Bricker JT, Chaitman BR, Fletcher GF, Froelicher VF, Mark DB, McCallister BD, Mooss AN, O'Reilly MG, Winters WL Jr. ACC/AHA 2002 guideline update for exercise testing: a report of the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association Task Force on Practice Guidelines (Committee on Exercise Testing). 2002. American College of Cardiology Web site. Available at: www.acc.org/clinical/guidelines/exercise/dirIndex.htm.)

The individual has coronary artery disease (CAD). (Gibbons RJ, Balady GJ, Bricker JT, Chaitman BR, Fletcher GF, Froelicher VF, Mark DB, McCallister BD, Mooss AN, O'Reilly MG, Winters WL Jr. ACC/AHA 2002 guideline update for exercise testing: a report of the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association Task Force on Practice Guidelines (Committee on Exercise Testing). 2002. American College of Cardiology Web site. Available at: www.acc.org/clinical/guidelines/exercise/dirIndex.htm.)

The likelihood an individual will develop coronary artery disease (CAD) is minimal or less than10%.(Gibbons RJ, Balady GJ, Bricker JT, Chaitman BR, Fletcher GF, Froelicher VF, Mark DB, McCallister BD, Mooss AN, O'Reilly MG, Winters WL Jr. ACC/AHA 2002 guideline update for exercise testing: a report of the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association Task Force on Practice Guidelines (Committee on Exercise Testing). 2002. American College of Cardiology Web site. Available at: www.acc.org/clinical/guidelines/exercise/dirIndex.htm.)

codelists.definition: A terminology codelist that contains symptoms associated with coronary artery disease.
codelists.name: Coronary Artery Disease Symptoms
synonyms: CDISC SDTM Coronary Artery Disease Symptoms Terminology

terms.definition: Sharp stabbing chest pain or reproduction of pain on palpation. Less common isolated presentations, primarily in older adults, include nausea and vomiting, diaphoresis, and unexplained fatigue. J Am Coll Cardiol, 2007; 50:1-157, doi:10.1016/j.jacc.2007.02.013 (Published online 6 August 2007).
The finding of no indications of a particular disease or injury.
A discomfort in the chest area that is not related to the heart.

Deep, poorly localized chest or arm discomfort that is reproducibly associated with physical exertion or emotional stress and is relieved promptly (ie, in less than 5 minutes) with rest and/or the use of sublingual nitroglycerin. Some patients may have no chest discomfort but present solely with jaw, neck, ear, arm, shoulder, back, or epigastric discomfort or with unexplained dyspnea without discomfort. If these symptoms have a clear relationship to exertion or stress or are relieved promptly with nitrates, they should be considered equivalent to angina. J Am Coll Cardiol, 2007; 50:1-157, doi:10.1016/j.jacc.2007.02.013 (Published online 6 August 2007).

codelists.definition: A codelist to describe whether the posterior descending artery comes from the right or left vessel system.
codelists.name: Coronary Artery Dominance
synonyms: CDISC SDTM Coronary Artery Dominance Terminology

terms.definition: The right coronary artery supplies the posterior descending artery (PDA) and the circumflex supplies the posterolateral artery (PLA). Thus, there is approximately equal contribution to the inferior surface of the left ventricle from both the left circumflex and right coronary arteries.
The posterior descending artery (PDA) and posterolateral artery (PLA) arises from the left circumflex artery.
The posterior descending artery (PDA) and posterolateral artery (PLA) arises from the right coronary artery.

codelists.definition: Classification system test code for cardiac parameters that are authored or endorsed by organizations.
codelists.name: Consensus Cardiac Classification System Test Code
codelists.preferredTerm: Consensus Cardiac Classification System Test Code
codelists.submissionValue: Consensus Cardiac Classification System Test Code
synonyms: CDISC SDTM Consensus Cardiac Classification Systems Test Code Terminology

terms.definition: A finding associated with a patient based on the functional classification developed by the Canadian Cardiovascular Society (CCS), for categorizing patients with angina. The classification system comprises four classes, which are defined in terms of the level of physical activity associated with the subject's anginal symptoms.
terms.submissionValue: Consensus Cardiac Classification System Test Code

terms.definition: A finding associated with a patient based on the classification developed by Killip and Kimball, which classifies patients with myocardial infarction based on routine physical examination parameters, such as the presence or absence of rales, or a decreased systolic blood pressure.
terms.submissionValue: Consensus Cardiac Classification System Test Code

terms.definition: A classification system for coronary stenosis based upon characteristics that influence the difficulty of percutaneous coronary revascularization.
terms.submissionValue: Consensus Cardiac Classification System Test Code
synonyms: American College of Cardiology American Heart Association Lesion Complexity Class

terms.definition: A finding associated with a patient based on the functional classification developed by the New York Heart Association (NYHA), for categorizing patients with defined or presumed cardiac disease. The classification system is based on the ability to engage in physical activity. The classification system comprises four classes, though NYHA Class III and Class IV are often aggregated for the purpose of outcomes analysis.
terms.submissionValue: Consensus Cardiac Classification System Test Code

terms.definition: A grading system for coronary blood flow based on the classification developed by the Thrombolysis in Myocardial Infarction Group. It classifies coronary blood flow into four classes based upon the angiographic appearance of the blood vessels.
terms.submissionValue: Consensus Cardiac Classification System Test Code

codelists.definition: Classification system test name for cardiac parameters that are authored or endorsed by organizations.
codelists.name: Consensus Cardiac Classification System Test Name
codelists.preferredTerm: Consensus Cardiac Classification System Test Name
codelists.submissionValue: Consensus Cardiac Classification System Test Name
synonyms: CDISC SDTM Consensus Cardiac Classification Systems Test Name Terminology

terms.definition: A finding associated with a patient based on the functional classification developed by the Canadian Cardiovascular Society (CCS), for categorizing patients with angina. The classification system comprises four classes, which are defined in terms of the level of physical activity associated with the subject's anginal symptoms.
terms.submissionValue: Consensus Cardiac Classification System Test Name

terms.definition: A finding associated with a patient based on the classification developed by Killip and Kimball, which classifies patients with myocardial infarction based on routine physical examination parameters, such as the presence or absence of rales, or a decreased systolic blood pressure.
terms.submissionValue: Consensus Cardiac Classification System Test Name

terms.definition: A classification system for coronary stenosis based upon characteristics that influence the difficulty of percutaneous coronary revascularization.
terms.submissionValue: Consensus Cardiac Classification System Test Name
synonyms: American College of Cardiology American Heart Association Lesion Complexity Class

terms.definition: A finding associated with a patient based on the functional classification developed by the New York Heart Association (NYHA), for categorizing patients with defined or presumed cardiac disease. The classification system is based on the ability to engage in physical activity. The classification system comprises four classes, though NYHA Class III and Class IV are often aggregated for the purpose of outcomes analysis.
terms.submissionValue: Consensus Cardiac Classification System Test Name

terms.definition: A grading system for coronary blood flow based on the classification developed by the Thrombolysis in Myocardial Infarction Group. It classifies coronary blood flow into four classes based upon the angiographic appearance of the blood vessels.
terms.submissionValue: Consensus Cardiac Classification System Test Name

codelists.definition: The effect that a cardiac rhythm device malfunction had on the ability to stimulate the heart.
codelists.name: Cardiac Rhythm Device Failure Manifestation
synonyms: CDISC SDTM Cardiac Rhythm Device Failure Manifestation Terminology

terms.definition: The cardiac rhythm device malfunction affected atrial pacing.
The cardiac rhythm device malfunction affected the defibrillator.
The cardiac rhythm device malfunction affected the left ventricular (LV) pacing.
The cardiac rhythm device malfunction affected the right ventricular (RV) pacing.

codelists.definition: The reason that a Coronary Sinus Access or Left Ventricular (CS/LV) lead was not implanted.
codelists.name: Reason CS/LV Lead Not Implanted
synonyms: CDISC SDTM Reason Coronary Sinus Access or Left Ventricular Lead Not Implanted Terminology

terms.definition: The coronary sinus/left ventricular lead was not implanted because the operator was unable to obtain acceptable pacing thresholds.
synonyms: Unable to Obtain Acceptable Pacing Thresholds

terms.definition: The coronary sinus/left ventricular lead was not implanted because the lead position resulted in undesirable stimulation of the diaphragm.
synonyms: Cardiac Lead Position Results in Undesirable Stimulation of Diaphragm

terms.definition: The coronary sinus/left ventricular lead was not implanted because a lead had been previously implanted.
The coronary sinus/left ventricular lead was not implanted because the operator was unable to obtain satisfactory coronary sinus access.
synonyms: Unable to Obtain Satisfactory Coronary Sinus Access

terms.definition: The coronary sinus/left ventricular lead was not implanted because the operator was unable to obtain satisfactory vascular access.
synonyms: Unable to Obtain Satisfactory Vascular Access

terms.definition: The coronary sinus/left ventricular lead was not implanted because the coronary sinus was dissected.
synonyms: Unable to Position Lead Due to Coronary Sinus Dissection

terms.definition: The coronary sinus/left ventricular lead was not implanted because the operator was unable to position the lead in the tributary vein of the coronary sinus.
synonyms: Unable to Position Lead In tributary Vein of Coronary Sinus

codelists.definition: A terminology codelist to describe the findings test code from a cardiac examination.
codelists.name: Cardiovascular Test Code
synonyms: CDISC SDTM Cardiovascular Test Code Terminology

terms.definition: The contribution of blood supply from the right or left vessel system to the posterior descending artery. (ACC)
terms.preferredTerm: Coronary Artery Dominance; Coronary Anatomy Dominance

terms.definition: The qualitative measurement of the severity of cardiac valvular regurgitation.
The qualitative measurement of the severity of cardiac valvular stenosis.
The percentage of myocardial tissue which exhibits characteristics of inadequate blood flow (ischemia).
The diameter across the left atrium measured at the end of systole.
The diameter across the ventricle at the end of diastole, excluding the thickness of the walls.
The diameter across the ventricle at the end of systole, excluding the thickness of the walls.

The percent or fraction of the left ventricular end diastolic volume ejected in systole. The left ventricular ejection fraction is equal to the left ventricular stroke volume divided by the left ventricular end diastolic volume.
Number of major epicardial vessels with greater than or equal to 70% reduction in diameter or greater than or equal to 50% reduction in cross-sectional area.
synonyms: Number of Diseased Coronary Artery Vessels

codelists.definition: A terminology codelist to describe the findings test name from a cardiac examination.
codelists.name: Cardiovascular Test Name
synonyms: CDISC SDTM Cardiovascular Test Name Terminology

terms.definition: The contribution of blood supply from the right or left vessel system to the posterior descending artery. (ACC)
terms.preferredTerm: Coronary Artery Dominance; Coronary Anatomy Dominance

terms.definition: The qualitative measurement of the severity of cardiac valvular regurgitation.
The qualitative measurement of the severity of cardiac valvular stenosis.
The percentage of myocardial tissue which exhibits characteristics of inadequate blood flow (ischemia).
The diameter across the left atrium measured at the end of systole.
The diameter across the ventricle at the end of diastole, excluding the thickness of the walls.
The diameter across the ventricle at the end of systole, excluding the thickness of the walls.

The percent or fraction of the left ventricular end diastolic volume ejected in systole. The left ventricular ejection fraction is equal to the left ventricular stroke volume divided by the left ventricular end diastolic volume.
Number of major epicardial vessels with greater than or equal to 70% reduction in diameter or greater than or equal to 50% reduction in cross-sectional area.
synonyms: Number of Diseased Coronary Artery Vessels

codelists.definition: A terminology codelist to describe the severity of cardiac valvular stenosis.
codelists.name: Cardiac Valvular Stenosis Severity
synonyms: CDISC SDTM Cardiac Valvular Stenosis Severity Terminology

terms.definition: The cardiac valve orifice is abnormally narrow, to a mild degree.
The cardiac valve orifice is abnormally narrow, to a moderate degree.
The cardiac valve orifice is not abnormally narrow.
The cardiac valve orifice is abnormally narrow, to a severe degree.

codelists.definition: A terminology codelist to describe the severity of cardiac valvular regurgitation.
codelists.name: Cardiac Valvular Regurgitation Severity
synonyms: CDISC SDTM Cardiac Valvular Regurgitation Severity Terminology

terms.definition: Evidence of mild retrograde blood flow through the valve(s) of the heart.
Evidence of moderate retrograde blood flow through the valve(s) of the heart.
No evidence of any retrograde blood flow through the valve(s) in the heart.
Evidence of severe retrograde blood flow through the valve(s) of the heart.

codelists.definition: The reason that a subject had a cardiac procedure.
codelists.name: Cardiac Procedure Indication
synonyms: CDISC SDTM Cardiac Procedure Indication Terminology

terms.definition: The intended recipient of a heart transplant.
An episode of cardiac arrest or arrhythmia where the etiology was unknown.

A disease of the heart muscle or myocardium proper. Cardiomyopathies may be classified as either primary or secondary, on the basis of etiology, or on the pathophysiology of the lesion: hypertrophic, dilated, or restrictive.
A longstanding, complete blockage of a vessel.
The subject contributing a heart for a cardiac transplant.
The battery that supplies the device has reached the end of its life.
There is a faulty connector/header in the device.
A cardiac lead requires revision, at which time the generator to the device will be replaced.
synonyms: Cardiac Device Generator is Being Replaced at Time of Lead Revision

terms.definition: The device has a generator malfunction.
An immediate percutaneous coronary intervention is necessary for a myocardial infarction that presents with ST segment elevation.
synonyms: Immediate Percutaneous Coronary Intervention for ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction

terms.definition: A disorder resulting from the presence and activity of a microbial, viral, or parasitic agent. It can be transmitted by direct or indirect contact. -- 2003 (NCI)
A cardiac lead has damaged local tissue enough to require treatment.
The degree of impairment of the left cardiac ventricle to contract efficiently.
An imperative issued by the manufacturer of a device that the device needs to be returned to a designated source for repair or replacement.
The device manufacturer had recognized a recurrent performance failure in the device.
synonyms: Manufacturer Recognized a Recurring Performance Failure

terms.definition: The medical condition or the procedure affects the device implantation site.
synonyms: Medical Condition or Procedure Affects Implantation Site

terms.definition: An intended medical or surgical procedure necessitates the relocation of a cardiac lead.
synonyms: Medical or Surgical Procedure Requiring Relocation of Lead

terms.definition: Includes patients with unstable angina or Non-STEMI who have high risk features for short-term risk of death or nonfatal MI. High risk features includes at least one of the following: history of accelerating tempo of ischemic symptoms in preceding 48 hours; character of pain - prolonged ongoing (greater than 20 minutes) rest pain; clinical findings - pulmonary edema, most likely due to ischemia or new or worsening mitral regurgitation murmur; or S3 or new worsening rales or Hypotension, bradycardia, tachycardia or age greater than 75 years; ECG - angina at rest with transient ST-segment changes greater than 0.5 mm or bundle-branch block, new or presumed new or sustained ventricular tachycardia; cardiac markers - NSTEMI patients with elevated cardiac TnT, Tnl, or CK-MB.
synonyms: Percutaneous Coronary Intervention for High Risk Non-ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction or Unstable Angina

terms.definition: A percutaneous coronary intervention is necessary for a myocardial infarction that presents with ST segment elevation and the subject does not have recurrent or persistent symptoms, symptoms of heart failure or ventricular arrhythmia after a successful dose of thrombolytic therapy.
synonyms: Percutaneous Coronary Intervention for ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction-Stable After Successful Full-Dose Thrombolytic Therapy

terms.definition: A percutaneous coronary intervention is necessary for a myocardial infarction that presents with ST segment elevation and the subject does not have recurrent or persistent symptoms, symptoms of heart failure or ventricular arrhythmia. The presentation is past twelve hours since onset of symptoms.
synonyms: Percutaneous Coronary Intervention for ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction-Stable-Over 12 Hours From Symptom Onset

terms.definition: A percutaneous coronary intervention is necessary for a myocardial infarction that presents with ST segment elevation and the subject has recurrent or persistent symptoms, symptoms of heart failure or ventricular arrhythmia. The presentation is past twelve hours since onset of symptoms.
synonyms: Percutaneous Coronary Intervention for ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction-Unstable-Over 12 Hours From Symptom Onset

terms.definition: A procedure to evaluate the health of the an individual after receiving a heart transplant.
A procedure to evaluate the health of the cardiac system to determine feasibility of a non-cardiac related surgical procedure.
A procedure performed to avoid the first occurrence of a disease condition.
A percutaneous coronary intervention is imperative for a myocardial infarction that presents with ST segment elevation after an unsatisfactory response to a full dose of thrombolytic therapy.
synonyms: Rescue Percutaneous Coronary Intervention for ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction After Failed Full-Dose Thrombolytic Therapy

terms.definition: A procedure performed to avoid a subsequent occurrence of a disease condition.
Ventricular tachycardia that occurs without provocation and does not resolve spontaneously.
A subsequent Percutaneous Coronary Intervention in a planned series of procedures, where the first PCI could have been during a prior admission, or during this admission.

A sudden loss of consciousness with loss of postural tone not related to anesthesia with high risk characteristics. High risk characteristics include non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, or ischemic heart disease with significant ventricular dysfunction, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, Brugada Syndrome, or Long QT Syndrome.
synonyms: Syncope with High Risk Cardiac Characteristics

terms.definition: Sudden loss of consciousness with loss of postural tone not related to anesthesia with ventricular tachycardia (VT) that can be induced during an electrophysiological study.
Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused. (NCI)
A device with additional pacing capabilities is replacing the current device.
synonyms: Upgrade to Cardiac Device with Additional Pacing Capabilities

terms.definition: Ventricular Fibrillation is characterized by rapid, usually more than 300 bpm (cycle length: 180 ms or less), grossly irregular ventricular rhythm with marked variability in QRS cycle length, morphology, and amplitude.

codelists.definition: A terminology codelist to describe the extent of coronary artery disease.
codelists.name: Coronary Vessel Disease Extent
synonyms: CDISC SDTM Coronary Vessel Disease Extent Terminology

terms.definition: Cannot distinguish between two or more possible values in the current context. (NCI)
There was less than 50% stenosis (reduction in cross-sectional area) in all coronary artery branches.
synonyms: No Evidence of Coronary Artery Disease

terms.definition: There was greater than or equal to 50% stenosis (reduction in cross-sectional area) in one coronary artery.

There was greater than or equal to 50% stenosis (reduction in cross-sectional area) in three coronary arteries (or greater than or equal to 50% stenosis in the left main coronary artery and greater than or equal to 50% stenosis in the right coronary artery).
There was greater than or equal to 50% stenosis (reduction in cross-sectional area) in two coronary arteries (or greater than or equal to 50% stenosis in the left main coronary artery).
Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused. (NCI)

codelists.definition: A terminology codelist that describes the treatment method for diabetes.
codelists.name: Diabetes Therapy

terms.definition: A form of therapy which includes dietary approaches and special diets.
A synthetic or animal-derived form of insulin used in the treatment of diabetes mellitus.
No treatment for diabetes.
A pharmacological medication intended for administration through the mouth.

codelists.definition: The destination or circumstance at the time of discharge.
codelists.name: Discharge Disposition

terms.definition: The absence of life or state of being dead. (NCI)
The patient died while in a medical center such as a hospital, skilled nursing facility (SNF), intermediate care facility (ICF), or a freestanding hospice center.
The patient will be admitted to a medical center that is funded by the federal government (e.g. Veterans Affairs Hospital).
The patient will return home but personal health maintenance will be administered and monitored by a member of a healthcare organization that is eligible to receive Medicare funding.
synonyms: Home Under Care of Organized Home Health Service Organization in Anticipation of Covered Skilled Care

terms.definition: The patient will receive end-of-life care which will be administered in the patient's home.
A routine discharge where personal health maintenance will be administered and monitored by the patient from their home.
The patient will receive end-of-life care which will be administered in a medical center.
The patient will be admitted into a medical center and receive a type of hospital bed that will be paid for my Medicare.
synonyms: Hospital with Medicare Approved Swing Bed

terms.definition: The patient will be admitted full time into a free standing rehabilitation center or a rehabilitation center within a general medical facility.
synonyms: Inpatient Rehabilitation Facility Including Rehabilitation distinct Part Units of a Hospital

terms.definition: The patient will be admitted into an alternative facility not listed.
The patient will be admitted into a medical center that provides care 24 hours per day.
The patient vacated the medical center or ceased medical care contrary to the recommendation of a trained healthcare provider.
The patient will be admitted into a Medicare funded medical center for a considerable length of time.
synonyms: Medicare Certified Long Term Care Hospital

terms.definition: The patient will be admitted into a medical center which is eligible to receive funding from Medicaid but not Medicare.
synonyms: Nursing Facility Certified Under Medicaid but Not Certified Under Medicare

terms.definition: The patient will be admitted into a free standing medical facility or a unit within a general medical facility used for the treatment of mental health disorders.
The patient will remain in a basic hospital environment for a brief time.
The patient will be admitted into a medical center equipped with a trained nursing staff that is eligible to receive Medicare funding.
synonyms: Skilled Nursing Facility with Medicare Certification in Anticipation of Covered Skilled Care

codelists.definition: Terminology used to describe the part of the graft that is most severely stenotic.
codelists.name: Location of Most Severe Stenosis Within a Graft
codelists.preferredTerm: Location of Most Severe Stenosis Within a Graft
codelists.submissionValue: Location of Most Severe Stenosis Within a Graft
synonyms: CDISC SDTM Location of Most Severe Stenosis Within a Graft Terminology

terms.definition: The connection where the graft joins the aorta usually less than or equal to 3 mm from insertion point.
terms.submissionValue: Location of Most Severe Stenosis Within a Graft

terms.definition: The portion of the graft that lies between its anastomoses.
terms.submissionValue: Location of Most Severe Stenosis Within a Graft

terms.definition: The connection where the graft joins the coronary artery usually less than or equal to 3 mm from insertion point.
terms.submissionValue: Location of Most Severe Stenosis Within a Graft

codelists.definition: A terminology codelist based on the classification developed by Killip and Kimball, which classifies patients with myocardial infarction based on routine physical examination parameters, such as the presence or absence of rales, or a decreased systolic blood pressure.
codelists.name: Killip Class Responses
synonyms: CDISC SDTM Killip Class Responses Terminology

terms.definition: The absence of rales over the lung fields and absence of third heart sound (S3). (ACC/AHA)
The presence of rales over 50% or less of the lung fields or the presence of a third heart sound (S3).(ACC/AHA)
The presence of rales over more than 50% of the lung fields. (ACC/AHA)
The presence of cardiogenic shock (systolic BP less than 90 mm Hg) for greater than 30 minutes, not responsive to fluid resuscitation alone, and felt to be secondary to cardiac dysfunction. (ACC/AHA)

codelists.definition: Terminology related to the complications of cardiac lead systems.
codelists.name: Lead Abnormality

terms.definition: Conductor failure manifests by high lead impedance either absolutely (above manufacturer's product specifications) or by a significant increase from previously stable chronic values.
The cardiac lead is not performing as expected with issues such as oversensing with or without shock or ATP, or failed shocks or inadequate DFT safety margins defibrillation activity.
This manifests as stimulation by the lead of non-cardiac structures such as the diaphragm, chest wall, or pectoral muscle.
The cardiac lead failed to administer a shock and had an inadequate defibrillator threshold safety margin.
synonyms: Failure to Shock with Inadequate Defibrillator Threshold Safety Margin

terms.definition: Failure to capture manifests as a high pacing threshold that results in either intermittent failure to capture at maximal programmed output or excessive battery drain leading to premature battery exhaustion.
synonyms: Failure to Capture with Acceptable Safety Margin

terms.definition: Failure to pace manifests as absence of pacemaker stimulation artifacts on electrocardiographic recordings despite rates below pacemaker programmed rate.
synonyms: Failure of Cardiac Pacemaker to Pace

terms.definition: Insulation failure manifests as low lead impedance either absolutely (below manufacturer's product specifications) or by a significant decrease from previously stable chronic values.
The movement (macroscopic or microscopic) of an existing lead within the heart or vascular tree away from the original implantation site.
Oversensing manifests as sensing of electrical signals not related to cardiac depolarization of the lead chamber that cannot be resolved acceptably by device reprogramming.
This manifests as sensing of non-cardiac depolarization signals that met arrhythmia detection criteria and elicited programmed tachyarrhythmia therapy.
synonyms: Cardiac Device Oversensing with Shock or Anti-Tachycardia Pacing

terms.definition: This manifests as sensing of non-cardiac depolarization signals that did not meet arrhythmia detection criteria and do not elicit programmed tachyarrhythmia therapy.
synonyms: Cardiac Device Oversensing without Shock or Anti-Tachycardia Pacing

terms.definition: The pacing and/or sensing problem associated with high impedance due to a poor connection between a lead and generator caused by a loose set screw.
Undersensing manifests as failure to sense appropriate cardiac depolarizations that cannot be resolved with reprogramming.

codelists.definition: The status of the lead.
codelists.name: Lead Status

terms.definition: The lead has been left in situ but is not in use.
The lead has been removed from the body.
The lead has been left in situ and reused.

codelists.definition: Terminology related to the risk of percutaneous coronary intervention for a particular lesion.
codelists.name: Lesion Complexity

terms.definition: Discrete (less than 10 mm length) and concentric and readily accessible and non-angulated segment less than 45 degrees and smooth contour and little or no calcification and less than totally occlusive and not ostial in location and no major branch involvement and absence of thrombus.
synonyms: American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association Lesion Complexity Score A

terms.definition: Tubular (10-20 mm length) or eccentric or moderate tortuosity of proximal segment or moderately angulated segment, 45-90 degrees or irregular contour or moderate to heavy calcification or ostial in location or bifurcation lesions requiring double guidewires or some thrombus present or total occlusion less than3 months old.
synonyms: American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association Lesion Complexity Score B

terms.definition: Diffuse (length greater than 2cm) or excessive tortuosity of proximal segment or extremely angulated segments greater than 90 degrees or total occlusions greater than 3 months old and/or bridging collaterals or inability to protect major side branches or degenerated vein grafts with friable lesions.
synonyms: American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association Lesion Complexity Score C

codelists.definition: Terminology for results of left ventricular ejection fraction assessments.
codelists.name: Left Ventricular Ejection Fraction Measurement Result
codelists.preferredTerm: Left Ventricular Ejection Fraction Measurement Result
codelists.submissionValue: Left Ventricular Ejection Fraction Measurement Result
synonyms: CDISC SDTM Left Ventricular Ejection Fraction Measurement Result Terminology

terms.definition: A pathologically high percentage of blood that is forced from the heart ventricle to produce cardiac output. This is often the result of ventricular dilation due to hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Quantitatively, the ejection fraction is considered higher than 70%.
terms.submissionValue: Left Ventricular Ejection Fraction Measurement Result

terms.definition: Slightly less than normal amount of blood that is forced from the heart ventricle to produce cardiac output. Quantitatively, the ejection fraction is considered between 40% to 49%.
terms.submissionValue: Left Ventricular Ejection Fraction Measurement Result

terms.definition: Moderately less than normal amount of blood that is forced from the heart ventricle to produce cardiac output. Quantitatively, the ejection fraction is considered between 30% to 39%.
terms.submissionValue: Left Ventricular Ejection Fraction Measurement Result

terms.definition: The usual amount of blood that is forced from the heart ventricle to produce cardiac output. Quantitatively, the ejection fraction is considered between 50% to 70%.
terms.submissionValue: Left Ventricular Ejection Fraction Measurement Result

terms.definition: Severely less than normal amount of blood that is forced from the heart ventricle to produce cardiac output. Quantitatively, the ejection fraction is considered less than 30%.
terms.submissionValue: Left Ventricular Ejection Fraction Measurement Result

codelists.definition: A terminology codelist to describe the timing of mechanical circulatory support placement.
codelists.name: Mechanical Circulatory Support Placement Timing
synonyms: CDISC SDTM Mechanical Circulatory Support Placement Timing Terminology

terms.definition: Mechanical Circulatory Support was in place at the start of the procedure.
terms.preferredTerm: In Place at Start of Procedure
synonyms: Mechanical Circulatory Support in Place at Start of Procedure

terms.definition: Mechanical Circulatory Support was inserted during a non-Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI) procedure.
terms.preferredTerm: Inserted during a Non PCI Procedure
synonyms: Inserted During a Non-Percutaneous Coronary Intervention

terms.definition: Mechanical Circulatory Support was inserted during the procedure after Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI) started.
terms.preferredTerm: Inserted during Procedure and after PCI Started
synonyms: Inserted During Procedure and After Percutaneous Coronary Intervention Began

terms.definition: Mechanical Circulatory Support was inserted during the procedure prior to percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).
terms.preferredTerm: Inserted during Procedure but Prior to PCI
synonyms: Inserted During a Procedure but Prior to Percutaneous Coronary Intervention

codelists.definition: A terminology codelist to describe a normal or abnormal response.
codelists.name: Normal Abnormal Response
synonyms: CDISC SDTM Normal Abnormal Response Terminology

terms.definition: Deviating in any way from the state, position, structure, condition, behavior, or rule which is considered a norm. (NCI)
Cannot distinguish between two or more possible values in the current context. (NCI)
Being approximately average or within certain limits; conforming with or constituting a norm or standard or level or type or social norm. (NCI)
Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused. (NCI)

codelists.definition: A terminology codelist that contains reasons for non-system PCI delay.
codelists.name: Non-system Reason for PCI Delay
synonyms: CDISC SDTM Non-system Reason for PCI Delay Terminology

terms.definition: Cardiac arrest which occurs before a percutaneous coronary intervention can take place.
synonyms: Cardiac Arrest Prior to Percutaneous Coronary Intervention

terms.definition: Access to the subject's vasculature is troublesome or formidable.
Placement of intracoronary devices across the coronary stenosis is troublesome or formidable.
synonyms: Difficulty Crossing Culprit Lesion During Percutaneous Coronary Intervention

terms.definition: Endotracheal intubation which occurs before a percutaneous coronary intervention can take place.
synonyms: Endotracheal Intubation before Percutaneous Coronary Intervention

terms.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned. (NCI)
The subject has not provided consent in a timely manner for the procedure to take place.

codelists.definition: A terminology codelist based on the functional classification developed by the New York Heart Association (NYHA), for categorizing patients with defined or presumed cardiac disease.
codelists.name: New York Heart Association Class Responses
codelists.preferredTerm: New York Heart Association Class Responses
codelists.submissionValue: New York Heart Association Class Responses
synonyms: CDISC SDTM New York Heart Association Class Responses Terminology

terms.definition: Without limitations of physical activity. Ordinary physical activity does not cause undue fatigue, palpitations, or dyspnea.
terms.preferredTerm: New York Heart Association Class I
terms.submissionValue: New York Heart Association Class Responses
synonyms: New York Heart Association Class I

terms.definition: Slight limitation of physical activity. The patient is comfortable at rest. Ordinary physical activity results in fatigue, palpitations, or dyspnea.
terms.preferredTerm: New York Heart Association Class II
terms.submissionValue: New York Heart Association Class Responses
synonyms: New York Heart Association Class II

terms.definition: Marked limitation of physical activity. The patient is comfortable at rest. Less than ordinary activity causes fatigue, palpitations, or dyspnea.
terms.preferredTerm: New York Heart Association Class III
terms.submissionValue: New York Heart Association Class Responses
synonyms: New York Heart Association Class III

terms.definition: Inability to carry on any physical activity without discomfort. Heart failure symptoms are present even at rest or with minimal exertion.
terms.preferredTerm: New York Heart Association Class IV
terms.submissionValue: New York Heart Association Class Responses
synonyms: New York Heart Association Class IV

codelists.definition: A terminology codelist to describe an activity that produces an effect, or that is intended to alter the course of a disease in a patient or population.
codelists.name: Procedure

terms.definition: An invasive therapeutic procedure to destroy tissue in an accessory pathways in the atrioventricular conduction system that contributes to arrhythmia.
An invasive therapeutic procedure to destroy tissue in the cardiac atria that is the source of an arrhythmia.
An invasive therapeutic procedure to destroy tissue in the AV-node that contributes to arrhythmia.
An invasive therapeutic procedure to destroy tissue in the cardiac ventricles that is the source of an arrhythmia.
Dilation of the valve between the left ventricle of the heart and the aorta by inflating a balloon.
Surgery performed with the purpose of replacing a degenerated, calcified, malformed, dysfunctional, etc. aortic valve with a bioprosthetic, homograft, or autograft valve.
Repair of atrial septum.
An invasive procedure that includes an electronic device that stimulates both right and left cardiac ventricles to improve coordination of ventricular contraction.
A surgical procedure in which a damaged heart is removed and replaced by another heart from a suitable donor.
The administration of pharmacologic agents to correct abnormal heart rhythm.
The administration of electric current to correct abnormal heart rhythm.
Surgery performed to bypass partially or completely occluded coronary arteries, thereby increasing the blood supply of the heart.
terms.preferredTerm: CAB; CABG; Coronary Artery Bypass Graft; Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting; Heart Bypass; Aortocoronary Bypass; Coronary Artery Bypass; Coronary Artery Bypass Graft Surgery

terms.definition: A procedure involving an electronic device implanted in the body that delivers electrical stimulation to the heart to treat tachycardia. It may also have the capability to treat bradycardia.
A procedure involving one or more wires used for pacemaker or implantable defibrillator devices.
The therapeutic blockage of the muscular pouch in the left atrium.
synonyms: Intentional Left Cardiac Atrial Appendage Occlusion Procedure

terms.definition: A procedure involving a mechanical cardiac pump which receives blood from the left ventricle and delivers it to the aorta.
An examination and assessment of the inability of the left ventricle to effectively pump blood to the body.
synonyms: Left Cardiac Ventricular Systolic Dysfunction Evaluation

terms.definition: Dilation of the valve between the left atrium and the left ventricle of the heart by inflating a balloon.
Dilation of the valve between the left atrium and the left ventricle of the heart by use of a surgeon's finger or rigid instrument.
Surgery performed for the purpose of reducing regurgitation of the mitral valve.
Surgery performed with the purpose of replacing a degenerated, calcified, malformed, dysfunctional, etc. mitral valve with bioprosthetic, homograft or autograft valve.
An operative procedure that does not involve the heart or the blood vessels.
A procedure involving an electronic device that delivers electrical stimulation to the heart to treat bradycardia.

A procedure on the coronary arteries of the heart that is performed by the placement of an angioplasty guide wire, balloon, or other device (e.g. stent, atherectomy, brachytherapy, or thrombectomy catheter) into a native coronary artery or coronary artery bypass graft for the purpose of mechanical coronary revascularization.
Invasive procedure through a puncture in the skin, performed for the purpose of reducing regurgitation of the mitral valve.
Removal or resection of the pericardium.
A procedure in which an opening is made in the pericardium.
The aspiration of excess fluid between the pericardium and the heart.
Surgery performed with the purpose of replacing a degenerated, calcified, malformed, dysfunctional, etc. pulmonary valve with bioprosthetic, homograft or autograft valve.
Dilation of the valve between the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery of the heart by inflating a balloon.
A procedure involving a mechanical pump which receives blood from the right ventricle and delivers it to the pulmonary artery.
synonyms: Right Cardiac Ventricle Assist Device Procedure

terms.definition: A cardiac catheterization procedure to relieve symptoms in patients with severe obstructive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. A catheter is used to inject alcohol into a septal artery supplying the heart muscle responsible for the obstruction, destroying the muscle tissue and relieving the obstruction.
A cardiac procedure intended to inhibit atrial fibrillation, in which a series of incisions are made in the atria to block abnormal electrical circuits that contribute to atrial fibrillation.
Use of a thin tube to deliver an artificial valve apparatus between the left ventricle of the heart and the aorta.
Surgery performed for the purpose of reducing regurgitation of the cardiac valve between the right atrium and right ventricle.
Surgery performed with the purpose of replacing a degenerated, calcified, malformed, dysfunctional, etc. tricuspid valve with bioprosthetic, homograft or autograft valve.
Cardiac surgical procedure performed for the removal of an aneurysm from the ventricular wall.
Repair of ventricular septum.

codelists.definition: A terminology codelist that describes the degree of urgency for a procedure.
codelists.name: Procedure Urgency Status
synonyms: CDISC SDTM Procedure Urgency Status Terminology

terms.definition: Elective procedures can be deferred without increased risk of compromised outcome. Patient's clinical condition is currently stable and has been stable in the days/weeks prior. The clinical situation does not demand that the procedure take place at a specified time.

Emergency procedures must be performed as soon as possible because of substantial concerns that delay could lead to death. Clinical situation demands that procedure should be performed immediately or in next available room, even if it means another case must be rescheduled.

Performing a salvage procedure is the last resort. The clinical situation involves either ongoing life support measures, life support measures for more than 60 seconds during the prior 10 minutes, or unanticipated institution of extracorporeal circulatory support.

Deferring an urgent procedure increases risk of adverse outcome or clinical deterioration. Clinical situation warrants performing urgent procedures during the current episode of care to avoid compromising patient safety.

codelists.definition: A terminology codelist to describe the risk of a disease, disorder or abnormal condition.
codelists.name: Risk Assessment

terms.definition: The potential future harm that may arise from some present action or attribute or condition is almost certain.
The potential future harm that may arise from some present action or attribute or condition is moderate.
The potential future harm that may arise from some present action or attribute or condition is small.
Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused. (NCI)

codelists.definition: A terminology codelist that describes syndromes or conditions that put a subject at risk for sudden death.
codelists.name: Sudden Death Syndrome Type
synonyms: CDISC SDTM Sudden Death Syndrome Type Terminology

terms.definition: Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia in the absence of structural heart disease, associated with a baseline ECG pattern during sinus rhythm showing right bundle branch block with ST segment elevation in leads V1 through V3. It can also be characterized by documentation of ECG patterns associated with Brugada Syndrome, some of which may be unmasked when provoked with drugs. The most common genetic mutations identified for Brugada syndrome are in the sodium channel gene SCN5A.
terms.preferredTerm: Ventricular arrhythmia associated with Brugada syndrome

terms.definition: Ventricular Tachycardia associated with syncope and/or cardiac arrest triggered by emotion or exercise in patients whose baseline ECG is normal.
Ventricular tachycardia or ventricular fibrillation whose cause is unknown.

Long QT Syndrome includes prolongation of the corrected QT interval beyond 440 ms for adult males, 460 ms for adult females and 50 ms in the presence of ventricular depolarization abnormalities (i.e., bundle branch blocks or IVCB more than 120 ms. A normal QT interval in a resting ECG with a failure to shorten with an increase in heart rate qualifies as Long QT Syndrome.
terms.preferredTerm: Ventricular arrhythmia associated with long QT syndrome

terms.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned. (NCI)
Short QT Syndrome is characterized by a QT interval of less than or equal to 300 ms.
terms.preferredTerm: Ventricular arrhythmia associated with short QT syndrome

codelists.definition: Acceptable values to describe TIMI Flow.
codelists.name: TIMI Flow Responses
synonyms: CDISC SDTM Thrombolysis in Myocardial Infarction Flow Responses Terminology

terms.definition: No perfusion: No antegrade flow beyond the point of occlusion. (www.TIMI.org accessed 21SEP2011)

Penetration without perfusion: The contrast material passes beyond the area of obstruction, but fails to opacify the entire coronary bed distal to the obstruction for the duration of the cine run. (www.TIMI.org accessed 21SEP2011)

Partial reperfusion: The contrast material passes across the obstruction and opacifies the entire coronary bed distal to the obstruction. However, the rate of entry of contrast into the vessel distal to the obstruction and/or its rate of clearance from the distal bed are perceptibly slower than its entry into and/or clearance from comparable areas not perfused by the culprit vessel (e.g., the opposite coronary artery or coronary bed proximal to the obstruction).(www.TIMI.org accessed 21SEP2011)

Complete perfusion: Antegrade flow into the bed distal to the obstruction occurs as promptly as into the bed proximal to the obstruction and clearance of contrast material from the involved bed is as rapid as from an uninvolved bed in the same vessel or the opposite artery. (www.TIMI.org accessed 21SEP2011 )

codelists.definition: Terminology relevant to the identification and clinical investigation of disease contacts.
codelists.name: Contact Case Investigation Contact Type
synonyms: CDISC SDTM Contact Case Investigation Contact Type Terminology

terms.definition: A way of contracting a disease through everyday interactions (nonsexual) with an infected person.
A way of contracting a disease by interacting with an individual that has been exposed to the disease while undergoing a medical procedure.
synonyms: Contact With Exposure During Medical Procedure

terms.definition: A way of contracting a disease by physically associating with an infected group of individuals.
synonyms: Contact With Exposure In Crowd Setting

terms.definition: A way of contracting a disease by interacting with an individual that is considered at high risk for having the disease.
A way of contracting a disease through interactions with an infected person in the same residence.

codelists.definition: Terminology relevant to the physical location at which the medication or therapy was observed, by the healthcare provider, as being taken by the subject.
codelists.name: Directly Observed Therapy Location
synonyms: CDISC SDTM Directly Observed Therapy Location Terminology

terms.definition: A setting outside the clinic or a comparable health care facility, e.g. a doctor's office, the subject's home or workplace, a school, a public park, or a restaurant.
The buildings and organizations where healthcare services are provided.

codelists.definition: Terminology relevant to the state or condition of the microbe or lesion to indicate whether it is resistant to drugs normally used in treatment.
codelists.name: Drug Resistance Status
synonyms: CDISC SDTM Drug Resistance Status Terminology

terms.definition: Resistance to nearly all known drugs, particularly the most efficacious or non-first line drugs, used in the treatment of a particular disease.

Simultaneous resistance to a spectrum of unrelated drugs following exposure to a single agent. Mechanisms involve expression of multidrug efflux pumps (p-glycoprotein), altered glutathione metabolism, decreased topoisomerase II activity, and changes in various cellular proteins.
The growth of microorganisms are inhibited by the usually achievable concentrations of antimicrobial agent when the recommended dosage is used for the site of infection.

codelists.definition: Terminology relevant to the measurable result or effect of treatment on a disease.
codelists.name: Disease Outcome

terms.definition: There are no indicators of bacterial infection in an individual who previously had an infection.
There are indicators of bacterial infection in the individual who previously had an infection.
There are no signs or symptoms of disease in the individual who previously had a disease.
There are still signs or symptoms of disease in the individual who previously had an infection.
The return of a disease after a period of remission.

codelists.definition: Terminology relevant to the clinical evidence to support reason for re-treatment of disease.
codelists.name: Supporting Evidence for Re-Treatment
synonyms: CDISC SDTM Supporting Evidence for Re-Treatment Terminology

terms.definition: Objective evidence of bacterial infection perceptible to the examiner by laboratory procedure.
Objective evidence of disease perceptible to the examiner (sign) and subjective evidence of disease perceived by the subject (symptom).
Objective evidence of disease perceptible to the examiner by radiological procedure.

codelists.definition: Terminology relevant to the test names that describe findings about an event or intervention.
codelists.name: Findings About Test Name
synonyms: CDISC SDTM Findings About Test Name Terminology

terms.definition: The state or condition of not responding to a pharmacological agent.

codelists.definition: Terminology relevant to the test codes that describe findings about an event or intervention.
codelists.name: Findings About Test Code
synonyms: CDISC SDTM Findings About Test Code Terminology

terms.definition: The state or condition of not responding to a pharmacological agent.

codelists.definition: Terminology relevant to the standardized results, in character format, for laboratory tests.
codelists.name: Laboratory Test Standard Character Result
synonyms: CDISC SDTM Laboratory Test Standard Character Result Terminology

terms.definition: Straddling the dividing line between two categories.
Cannot distinguish between two or more possible values in the current context. (NCI)
Not valid data.
A finding of normality following an examination or investigation looking for the presence of a microorganism, disease, or condition.
An observation confirming something, such as the presence of a disease, condition, or microorganism.

codelists.definition: Terminology relevant to the degree of certainty of the correctness of a microbial identification test result.
codelists.name: Microbial Identification Certainty
synonyms: CDISC SDTM Microbial Identification Certainty Terminology

terms.definition: Supplying or being a final or conclusive settlement or result.
Supplying or being a probable or reasonable settlement or result.

codelists.definition: Terminology relevant to the prioritization of tuberculosis contacts.
codelists.name: Priority of Tuberculosis Contact
synonyms: CDISC SDTM Priority of Tuberculosis Contact Terminology

terms.definition: An individual that has tested positive for pulmonary, laryngeal, or pleural tuberculosis and may or may not present with cavitary disease.
An individual that has had limited exposure to an individual with tuberculosis and has a low probability of having had a recent infection.
An individual that has tested negative for pulmonary, laryngeal, or pleural tuberculosis but has had a non-cavitary chest x-ray that is consistent with tuberculosis.

codelists.definition: Terminology relevant to the reason the drug or therapy was temporarily ceased.
codelists.name: Reason for Treatment Interruption
synonyms: CDISC SDTM Reason for Treatment Interruption Terminology

terms.definition: A patient's failure to remember to take a dose of medication.
An inability to absorb or metabolize certain substances in the normal way.
Medications that were lost because they were put in the wrong place.
Failure of a patient to follow medical advice, take medication as directed, or adhere to a prescribed course of treatment.
The lack of expected or desired effect related to a therapy. (NCI)
Leisure time away from work devoted to rest or pleasure.

codelists.definition: Terminology relevant to the reason the treatment was administered.
codelists.name: Reason For Treatment
synonyms: CDISC SDTM Reason For Treatment Terminology

terms.definition: A lack of response to the first cycle of therapy.
A lack of response to more than one cycle of therapy.
A previous episode of failure by a patient to follow medical advice, take medication as directed, or adhere to a prescribed course of treatment.
The return of a disease after a period of remission.

codelists.definition: Terminology relevant to the reason the drug or therapy was unsuccessful in treating the condition.
codelists.name: Treatment Failure Reason
synonyms: CDISC SDTM Treatment Failure Reason Terminology

terms.definition: The mechanisms, functions, activities, or processes exhibited by microorganisms, especially bacteria, to resist or to become tolerant to antibiotics.
An indication that a medication schedule was modified by temporarily terminating a prescribed regimen of medication. (NCI)
Failure of a patient to follow medical advice, take medication as directed, or adhere to a prescribed course of treatment.
A drug serum concentration below therapeutic levels.

codelists.definition: Terminology relevant to the reason the treatment was not administered.
codelists.name: Reason Treatment Not Administered
synonyms: CDISC SDTM Reason Treatment Not Administered Terminology

terms.definition: The medication is no longer held or possessed by the subject and is incapable of being recovered or regained.
Is not an option.
To decline to do, accept, give, or allow something.
The act of changing your residence or place of business.

codelists.definition: Terminology relevant to the social factors such as personal behavior, lifestyle, or environment belonging to the subject which are known to increase the likelihood of infection and disease.
codelists.name: Social Risk Factor
synonyms: CDISC SDTM Social Risk Factor Terminology

terms.definition: An individual that came into contact with a source of Tuberculosis.
synonyms: Subject in Contact With Tuberculosis Source

terms.definition: An individual who is presently or not long ago worked or offered to assist without pay at a temporary housing facility for persons without a stable or permanent residence.
synonyms: Current or Recent Employee or Volunteer in Homeless Shelter

terms.definition: An individual who is presently or not long ago worked or offered to assist without pay at an institution where persons are confined for punishment and to protect the public.
synonyms: Current or Recent Employee or Volunteer in Jail or Prison

terms.definition: An individual who is presently or not long ago worked or offered to assist without pay at a residential health care facility for persons with chronic illness or disability.
synonyms: Current or Recent Employee or Volunteer in Nursing Home

terms.definition: An individual without a stable or permanent residence within the last 365 days.
An individual that has migrated from a country with a high occurrence of tuberculosis.
synonyms: Immigrant From High Tuberculosis Prevalent Area

terms.definition: The state of being confined to jail or prison.
An individual that resided in a camp for those displaced from their homeland.

An individual that lives at a healthcare facility that provides rehabilitative, restorative, and/or ongoing skilled nursing care to patients or residents in need of assistance with activities of daily living.
An individual who moves from one location to another location within or outside of their homeland for work.
An individual that has fled a country for their own safety which has a high occurrence of tuberculosis.
synonyms: Refugee From High Tuberculosis Prevalent Area

terms.definition: Entry into one or more of the 22 countries that have a relatively high prevalence of tuberculosis cases.
synonyms: Travel To High Burden Tuberculosis Country

terms.definition: The state of not having a job.

codelists.definition: Terminology relevant to the environment within which the subject may have come into contact with a disease carrier, or played the role of a disease carrier.
codelists.name: Contact Setting

terms.definition: A tract of land cultivated for the purpose of agricultural production or devoted to the raising and breeding of domestic animals.
The area in which an individual lives.
An area outside of that in which an individual lives.
An institution where persons are confined for punishment and to protect the public.
An educational institution.
The surroundings or environment in which social activities occur.
Place or physical location of work or employment.

codelists.definition: Terminology relevant to whether an individual is being treated for a disease for the first time.
codelists.name: Treatment Episode

terms.definition: Having no previous example or precedent or parallel; of a kind not seen before.
The repeated act of the dispensing, applying, or tendering of something to another after an initial treatment.

codelists.definition: Terminology relevant to the source of information regarding the subject's vaccination status.
codelists.name: Vaccination Evidence Source
synonyms: CDISC SDTM Vaccination Evidence Source Terminology

terms.definition: A mark left (usually on the skin) by the healing of injured tissue.
An individual's perspective or subjective interpretation of an event or information.
The collecting, abstracting, and coding of printed or written information for future reference.

codelists.definition: Terminology related to the classification of a CDISC domain.
codelists.name: General Observation Class
synonyms: CDISC SDTM General Observation Class Terminology

terms.definition: The Subject-Level Analysis Dataset (ADSL) is a one-record-per-subject dataset which contains variables that describe subject demographic characteristics and group the subjects for analysis. ADSL is the primary source for subject-level variables included in other analysis datasets such as population flags and treatment variables.

An ADaM BDS dataset contains one or more records per subject, per analysis parameter, per analysis time point. Variables include the value being analyzed (e.g., AVAL) and the description of the value being analyzed (e.g., PARAM). Other variables in the dataset provide more information about the value being analyzed (e.g., the subject identification) or describe and trace the derivation of it (e.g., DTYPE) or support the analysis of it (e.g., treatment variables, covariates).

This SDTM class captures planned protocol milestones such as randomization and study completion, and occurrences, conditions, or incidents independent of planned study evaluations occurring during the trial (e.g., adverse events) or prior to the trial (e.g., medical history).

This SDTM class captures investigational, therapeutic and other treatments that are administered to the subject (with some actual or expected physiological effect) either as specified by the study protocol (e.g., exposure to study drug), coincident with the study assessment period (e.g., concomitant medications), or self-administered by the subject (such as use of alcohol, tobacco, or caffeine).
An ADaM analysis dataset that doesn't conform to the ADSL or BDS structure.
This SDTM class provides a means to link related records between datasets. It includes the RELREC and SUPPQUAL datasets.
This SDTM class contains a set of domains which do not conform to the Findings, Events or Interventions observation classes. The domains included are DM, CO, SE and SV.

This SDTM class describes the plan for the procedures to be followed in a clinical trial, including planned and actual timing of events, control group, method of allocating treatments, blinding methods, assignment of epochs that subjects pass through in the course of a trial.
This SDTM class captures the observations resulting from planned evaluations to address specific tests or questions such as laboratory tests, ECG testing, and questions listed on questionnaires.
